column2:
COVID-19 negative certification required for entering the country require.
If you enter Moldova from Ukraine, you are exempted from all COVID-19 related documentation and checks. You will be exempt from self-isolation if you present one of the following documents:
• proof that you have received both doses of an approved vaccination. The second dose must have been administered at least 14 days before your date of arrival. Current rules do not specify whether electronic documents are acceptable as proof, but you are recommended to have your vaccination certificate in paper form.
• negative result of a PCR test taken no more than 72 hours before your time of arrival;
• negative result of a rapid antigen test taken no more than 48 hours hours before your time of arrival;
• a confirmation of the presence of COVID-19 antibodies (serological test) that is valid for a period of 90 days from the date of the test;
column3:
Self-isolation at own accommodation- if not in possession of pre-requisite documents.
If you enter Moldova from Ukraine, you are exempted from all COVID-19 related documentation and checks.
From 17 January 2022, on entering Moldova, all arrivals who don’t have one of the documents listed below, must complete an online epidemiological form that declares information about your state of health (relevant to COVID-19) and confirm that you will self-isolate for 14 days unless you are exempt.
The form should be completed within 72 hours before your scheduled departure to Moldova and can be found via the following link. You will be exempt from self-isolation if you present one of the following documents:
You will be exempt from self-isolation if you present one of the following documents:
• proof that you have received both doses of an approved vaccination. The second dose must have been administered at least 14 days before your date of arrival. Current rules do not specify whether electronic documents are acceptable as proof, but you are recommended to have your vaccination certificate in paper form.
• negative result of a PCR test taken no more than 72 hours before your time of arrival;
• negative result of a rapid antigen test taken no more than 48 hours hours before your time of arrival;
• a confirmation of the presence of COVID-19 antibodies (serological test) that is valid for a period of 90 days from the date of the test;
quarantine exemptions apply:
• children up to the age of 12 are fully exempt
• people in transit, who are not spending more than 24 hours after their entrance was recorded in Moldova
• students coming for studies, exams, or academic contests upon presenting confirmation papers;
• crew and service personnel of aircraft, ships, and trains;
• persons summoned by Moldovan law enforcement institutions;
• persons traveling for health reasons, including the attendant;
• personnel involved in providing humanitarian aid;
• diplomatic passport holders and their family members accredited to the Republic of Moldova and International UN staff;
Arrivals who are in self-isolation may take a PCR test or a rapid antigen test on the 7th day of their visit, and will not have to continue self-isolating if the test is negative. You are allowed to enter the Transnistrian region without a negative PCR test.

The second dose must have been administered at least 14 days before your date of arrival. Current rules do not specify whether electronic documents are acceptable as proof, but you are recommended to present your vaccination certificate in paper form.
column5:
Latest News:

International Restrictions:
*All travellers: All travellers should familiarise themselves with the entry rules for Moldova before travel.
*Entering Moldova from Ukraine: If you enter Moldova from Ukraine, you are exempted from all COVID-19 related documentation and checks. Border Police will permit you to cross the Ukrainian-Moldovan checkpoint with a national ID card or a birth certificate.
*Entering Moldova from all other countries: From 17 January 2022 all arrivals to Moldova must present one of the following documents to be exempt from the requirement to self-isolate:
• proof that you have received both doses of an approved vaccination. The second dose must have been administered at least 14 days before your date of arrival. Current rules do not specify whether electronic documents are acceptable as proof, but you are recommended to have your vaccination certificate in paper form
• negative result of a PCR test taken no more than 72 hours before your time of arrival
• negative result of a rapid antigen test taken no more than 48 hours before your time of arrival
• confirmation of the presence of COVID-19 antibodies (serological test) that is valid for a period of 90 days from the date of the test
All documents are accepted in the following languages: English, Romanian, Russian, French, Italian and German.
IMPORTANT: You can’t enter Moldova without any COVID-19 documentation (e.g. vaccination certificate, negative PCR test, lateral flow test or similar).
*Self-isolation requirement: If you don’t have one of the documents listed above, you must complete an online epidemiological form that declares information about your state of health (relevant to COVID-19) and confirm that you will self-isolate for 14 days, unless you are exempt.
The online epidemiological form should be completed within 72 hours before your scheduled departure to Moldova.
Arrivals who are in self-isolation may take a PCR test or a rapid antigen test on the 7th day of their visit, and will not have to continue self-isolating if the test is negative.
*If you’re fully vaccinated: If you’re fully vaccinated, you can enter Moldova without needing to provide a negative test or self-isolate.
You will need to present proof that you have received both doses of an approved vaccination. Current rules do not specify whether electronic documents are acceptable as proof, but it is recommended that you have your vaccination certificate in paper form.
*Proof of vaccination status: Moldova accepts the proof of COVID-19 recovery and vaccination record and proof of COVID-19 vaccination issued in the Crown Dependencies. Your final vaccine dose must have been administered at least 14 days before your date of arrival. Your appointment card from vaccination centres is not designed to be used as proof of vaccination and should not be used to demonstrate your vaccine status.
*If you’re not fully vaccinated: If you’re not fully vaccinated, you’ll need to present proof of a negative PCR test result, taken no more than 72 hours before your time of arrival, or a negative rapid antigen test result, taken no more than 48 hours before your time of arrival.
*If you’ve had COVID-19 in the past year: If you’ve tested positive for COVID-19 in the past year, you’ll need to present confirmation of the presence of COVID-19 antibodies (serological test) that is valid for a period of 90 days from the date of the test. You can use the proof of COVID-19 recovery record to demonstrate proof of COVID-19 recovery when entering Moldova.
*Children and young people: Children up to the age of 12 are fully exempt from the requirement to self-isolate on arrival to Moldova.
*If you’re transiting through Moldova: If you are transiting through Moldova and are not spending more than 24 hours in the country, you are exempt from the requirement to self-isolate.
Exemptions: The following groups are exempt from the self-isolation requirement:
• children up to the age of 12
• people in transit, who are not spending more than 24 hours after their entrance was recorded in Moldova
• students coming for studies, exams, or academic contests upon presenting confirmation papers
• crew and service personnel of aircraft, ships, and trains
• persons summoned by Moldovan law enforcement institutions
• persons traveling for health reasons, including the attendant
• personnel involved in providing humanitarian aid
• diplomatic passport holders and their family members accredited to the Republic of Moldova and International UN staff


Internal Restrictions:
*Travel in Moldova: There are no local travel restrictions in place in Moldova.
*Accommodation: Most hotels are open with no restrictive measures in place.
*Public places and services: Markets, restaurants and bars are operating usual hours, including food delivery services. Malls and commercial centres are operating usual working hours (until 10pm). Schooling is both online and in-person. Nightclubs are closed. Restaurants, cafes, theatres, cinemas and concert halls are open, but access will only be permitted upon presentation, either on paper or electronically, of one of the following documents (for persons over the age of 18):
• a COVID-19 vaccination certificate evidencing full vaccination;
• a negative PCR test result taken no more than 72 hours before the event;
• a negative rapid antigen test result taken no more than 48 hours before the event;
• confirmation of the presence of COVlD-19 antibodies (serological antibodies test).The document is valid for a period of 90 days from the date of the test.
You must also carry one form of photo identification as well as your COVID-19 document such as a passport or driving license.
You must wear a mask outside at mass gatherings, and in enclosed spaces such as supermarkets, restaurants, bars and on public transport. Officials have the authority to issue fines for non-compliance. Social distancing of 1m must be observed.
